intro: Leptosiphon lemmonii, commonly known as the desert milkvetch, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial shrub that typically reaches heights of 10 to 30 centimeters. The plant produces small, pea-like flowers that range in color from white to pink, often appearing in clusters along the stems. Its leaves are compound, consisting of several oval-shaped leaflets, and it has a deep root system adapted to arid environments. Leptosiphon lemmonii is often found in sandy or rocky soils and is well-suited to desert conditions.
